document_title: Establishment and characterization of DB-1: a leptin receptor-deficient murine macrophage cell line
summary_full: This study describes the establishment and characterization of DB-1, a novel immortalized macrophage cell line derived from leptin receptor-deficient (db/db) mice. The aim was to create an in vitro tool to investigate the role of leptin and its receptor in immune responses, particularly in the context of obesity-associated inflammation. DB-1 cells were generated from bone marrow cells differentiated with M-CSF, spontaneously immortalized, and cloned. The resulting cell line is diploid, exhibits macrophage markers (MAC-2 positive, F4/80 low, CD11b absent, Ly6C intermediate), possesses phagocytic activity comparable to primary macrophages, and responds to interferon-gamma (IFN-γ) by increasing Nos2 transcript levels. Crucially, DB-1 cells are unresponsive to leptin and adipocyte-conditioned media (ACM) in migration assays, unlike wild-type macrophages, confirming their leptin receptor deficiency. This cell line provides a valuable resource for studying leptin's influence on innate immunity and macrophage function.
key_findings: Established DB-1, a spontaneously immortalized, leptin receptor-deficient murine macrophage cell line.
DB-1 cells are diploid, possess macrophage lineage markers (MAC-2+, F4/80 low, CD11b-, Ly6C intermediate), and exhibit phagocytic activity similar to primary macrophages.
DB-1 cells are responsive to IFN-γ stimulation, showing increased Nos2 transcript levels and IL-6 secretion.
DB-1 cells are unresponsive to leptin and adipocyte-conditioned media in migration assays, confirming the absence of functional leptin receptors.
The cell line provides a tool to study the role of the leptin receptor in obesity-associated inflammation and immune dysregulation.
future_research_fields: Investigating the specific role of the leptin receptor in macrophage-mediated inflammatory responses in obesity.
Studying leptin's impact on antigen processing and presentation by macrophages.
Exploring the potential of DB-1 cells in adoptive transfer studies for in vivo research.
Further characterization of the molecular mechanisms underlying leptin's influence on immune cell trafficking and function.

conclusions: The establishment of the DB-1 cell line provides a valuable and dependable in vitro tool for investigating the specific roles of leptin and its receptor in innate immunity and obesity-associated inflammation. The cell line exhibits key macrophage characteristics and a confirmed deficiency in leptin receptor signaling, enabling focused research into these complex biological interactions.
impact_statement: This study provides a novel leptin receptor-deficient macrophage cell line that can advance research into the immunological consequences of obesity and the role of leptin in immune system regulation.
